#Text=David Hughson
#Text=Not to be confused with Edward Pugh ( artist ) .
#Text=Emblematical
#Text=Representation of Commerce and Plenty Presenting the City of London with the Riches of the Four Quarters of the World
#Text=, from Volume I of Hughson 's description of London .
#Text=David Hughson ( c. 1760s – 1820s ) , which may have been a pen name of Edward Pugh , was a writer on the topography and history of London .

#Text=He produced a description of the city based on " an actual perambulation " ( walk ) that was published in six volumes between 1805 and 1809 and contains 150 copper plate engravings principally based on illustrations by Robert Blemmell Schnebbelie and Edward Gyfford .

column1: #Text=He also produced works on topical matters such as the East India Company , religious subjects , and works of household management targeted at people of the " middling and genteel ranks of life " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=Life

#Text=Little is known of Hughson 's life other than that David Hughson was probably a pseudonym and that his real name may have been David Pugh , [ 2 ] or Daniel Pugh , [ 3 ] or Edward Pugh , [ 4 ] or R. Pugh . [ 5 ]

#Text=In his book The East-India Question Fairly Elucidated ( 1813 ) he described himself as a " native " of London and as having resided in the city for over 50 years , indicating that he may have been born in the early 1760s . [ 6 ]
#Text=The last original work published in his name was his 1829 revision of William Augustus Henderson 's Modern Domestic Cookery ( best known as the author of The Housekeeper 's Instructor ) .
#Text=In his works he is described as having the degree of LLD ( doctor of laws ) and , in one , of MD . [ 1 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Fish Street Hill , drawn by Edward Gyfford and engraved by John Roffe for Hughson 's description of London .
#Text=Published by J. Stratford , Holborn , October 1807 . [ 7 ]
#Text=Purfleet , drawn by Edward Gyfford and engraved by Sparrow , for Hughson 's description of London .
#Text=Published by J. Stratford , Holborn , December 1807 . [ 8 ]
#Text=Perambulation of London

#Text=Hughson is best known for his London ; Being an Accurate History and Description of the British Metropolis and its Neighbourhood , to Thirty Miles Extent which he prepared from " an actual perambulation " ( a real walk ) of the city .
#Text=The work was first published between 1805 and 1809 by James Stratford of Holborn in 149 parts of about 24 pages each for binding into six volumes .
#Text=After Stratford , it was also published by Joseph Robins of Tooley Street and parts by J. Robins of Ivy Lane , Paternoster Row .
#Text=It includes 150 copper plate engravings but also many engraved titles and small woodcut illustrations .
#Text=The engravings are mostly by Ambrose Warren from works by Robert Blemmell Schnebbelie and Edward Gyfford .
#Text=Other engravers who contributed were William Woolnoth , John Roffe and J. S. Storer . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1817 , he published Walks Through London ( 2 vols. ) which contained 96 copper engravings and 24 on wood .
#Text=The principal engravers and artists were J. Greig , T. Higham and W. Wallis .
#Text=J. C. Varrall , E.J. Roberts , W. Morland and C. J. M. Whichelo also contributed . [ 9 ]

#Text=Halkett and Laing , in their dictionary of anonymous and pseudonymous literature , give the author of this work as " Dr. R. Pugh " but say it has also been ascribed to William Hamilton Reid and Mrs Reid . [ 5 ]

#Text=Reid 's obituary in The Gentleman 's Magazine ( 1826 ) , however , states that although Reid prepared topographical notes on London , his research was unpublished at the time of his death . [ 10 ]
#Text=Domestic economy
#Text=In 1817 , he published The New Family Receipt-Book : Or Universal Repository of Domestic Economy .
#Text=The book collected recipes , medical information , advice on household management , and other material .
#Text=Among the contents are articles on an " Easy Method of Curing the Sea-Scurvy " and a method " To Increase the Force of Gun-Powder " . [ 11 ]
#Text=Arnold Oxford suggests it is an abbreviated version of the anonymous 1810 book , The Family Receipt-Book , the title page of which is almost identical . [ 12 ]

#Text=In 1829 , Modern Domestic Cookery , and Useful Receipt Book , Adapted for Families in the Middling and Genteel Ranks of Life was published in New York , stated to be written by W. A. Henderson ( author of The Housekeeper 's Instructor ) and " enlarged and improved by D. Hughson M.D. " [ 1 ]
#Text=Other works

#Text=In 1814 , he published A Copious Account of the French and English Prophets , Who Infested London During 1707 which dealt with the Camisard Huguenot preachers , the first of whom arrived in London in 1706 , and their fate .
#Text=In the same year he published the Quaker biography , The Life of James Nayler , A Fanatical Enthusiast , Who Profanely and Blasphemously Personated Jesus Christ .
#Text=Both were reprinted in M. Aikin 's Memoirs of Religious Impostors in 1821 . [ 13 ]
